comments.body: Is `libtool` required for run time?
Yes.
Sorry, I put this under build, but was a bit surprised that it is under run too.
We also have this for Mac in both cases. So, if we need it, it would be nice to have it on both platforms as a dependency.
Also, on OS X.
According to the Homebrew formula, support for libtool is present in Graphviz master, not in its latest release.
We have this on both Mac and Linux. So, can we please make this Unix or as @ocefpaf says drop the selector entirely?
I took a lot of time looking into the dependencies needed for both Linux and OS X. So I'm pretty sure the selectors are the right ones.
Same as above. Could we please make this Unix or drop the selector?
This is not needed on OS X.
Why not? This provides SVG support for Graphviz. I would really like to have it on Mac. Plus, it is good to try and standardize our Mac and Linux builds when it comes to dependencies.
Looks like we get SVG support without this on Mac. So, we can ignore it for now.
I guess this would be EPL, but I leave it up to you.
I don't think we (at Continuum) have a `license_family` entry for EPL. I think the main families are GPL, BSD and MIT (or something like that).
Ok, again we haven't been picky on this just offering it as an option. Happy with whatever you choose to do here. 😄

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +57,61 @@  home: http://www.graphviz.org/
  license: EPL v1.0
  license_family: Other
  summary: Open Source graph visualization software.
  description: |

comments.body: We have this on all platforms. So, there shouldn't be a need for a selector here.
There are linking problems if we use it. According to the Graphviz Homebrew formula, it's not needed.
Could you please clarify as to what linking problems you are seeing here?

The linker was complaining that it was unable to find the expat dynamic library.

I really don't know why, but since Homebrew doesn't require it, I just removed it from OS X.
Maybe there is some configure option needed here. Anyways, if we have SVG support without it, I don't really care so much.

> The linker was complaining that it was unable to find the expat dynamic library.

I believe the error you're referring to is this one, which occurs during `make install`:

```
Making install in dot
 ../../config/install-sh -c -d '/miniconda/envs/_build_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placeho/bin'
  /bin/sh ../../libtool   --mode=install /usr/bin/install -c dot dot_builtins '/miniconda/envs/_build_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placeho/bin'
libtool: install: /usr/bin/install -c .libs/dot /miniconda/envs/_build_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placeho/bin/dot
libtool: install: /usr/bin/install -c .libs/dot_builtins /miniconda/envs/_build_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placeho/bin/dot_builtins
/Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer/usr/bin/make  install-exec-hook
(cd /miniconda/envs/_build_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placeho/bin; if test -x dot; then for i in neato twopi fdp circo osage patchwork sfdp; do rm -f $i; ln -s dot $i; done; fi;)
if test "x" = "x"; then if test -x /miniconda/envs/_build_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placeho/bin/dot; then if test -x /sbin/ldconfig; then /sbin/ldconfig 2>/dev/null; fi; /miniconda/envs/_build_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placeho/bin/dot -c; else /miniconda/envs/_build_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placeho/bin/dot_static -c; fi; fi
dyld: Library not loaded: @rpath/libexpat.1.dylib
  Referenced from: /miniconda/envs/_build_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placeho/bin/dot
  Reason: Incompatible library version: dot requires version 8.0.0 or later, but libexpat.1.dylib provides version 7.0.0
/bin/sh: line 1: 94089 Trace/BPT trap: 5       /miniconda/envs/_build_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placehold_placeho/bin/dot -c
```

> I really don't know why, but since Homebrew doesn't require it, I just removed it from OS X.

I think Homebrew doesn't require it because it is apparently already installed on OS X in a system location: `/usr/lib/libexpat.1.dylib`.  Well, that's where it lives if you have the XCode command-line tools installed.  If you don't have the XCode command-line tools, I'm not sure where it lives (if it's present at all).

If we would prefer to use conda for `expat` instead of the system, we can fix the above-mentioned error with an extra command after `make`, but before `make install`.  If you think that change is worth making, I've submitted a PR-onto-this-PR:

https://github.com/ccordoba12/staged-recipes/pull/2

If you don't think it's worth it, then just ignore that PR :-)

OK, I take it back. That PR allows the recipe to build without errors, but it doesn't actually fix the links to `expat` in the final binary package -- the system `libexpat.1.dylib` is still used.  For now, let's just leave it alone.

I _think_ this means that Mac users will need the XCode command-line tools in order to use graphviz, but that's a reasonable requirement as far as I'm concerned.
Hmm...do you have a few minutes to sit down and play with this? It would be nice to use `expat` from conda-forge and maybe if we put our heads together we can fix this.

> do you have a few minutes to sit down and play with this?

Sorry, not today.  Maybe the best thing to do is to simply insert a comment into `meta.yaml` next to the `expat` requirement, with a link to this discussion.  Then we can come back to it later.
Nor a selector here as we have it on all platforms.
Why don't we need this on Linux? I would prefer to use our copy if there is no other reason.
Because we need the pkg-config from the system instead of the conda one to find the `gtk2-devel` files.
I think we can solve this with `PKG_CONFIG_PATH`, but it can be saved for the feedstock.

As a proposal, we could try using the commit for better stability. If you want, this can be added to the jinja header.

https://github.com/ellson/graphviz/archive/f54ac2c9313ae80ccf76ef4ac6aa9be820a23126.zip

comments.body: There wouldn't be a separate Windows section. Hope that is ok. I don't remember whether there was a significant difference between the two.

This zip file contains a binary build of Graphviz, so we can't get rid of it.

I looked into compiling Graphviz from sources but it doesn't seem an easy task. Let's leave that for the feedstock.

SGTM. This was more a comment on if the website stayed broken.

Though we should open an issue in the feedstock to remind us about this.
